G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of the Norfolk Probate and Family Court (“this Court”) pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, and related statutes governing custody and parenting orders involving minor children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of the Norfolk Probate and Family Court (“this Court”) pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, and related statutes governing custody and parenting orders involving minor children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting-time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the minor children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting-time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the minor children.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting-time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the minor children.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, not modification of custody or parenting-time provisions. The court discusses standards for modifying support orders (material change in circumstances, needs of the children, and financial status of the provider) and the probate court’s continuing authority to revise support, but it does not address custody or visitation/parenting-time jurisdiction or standards. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting-time orders.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28…”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting-time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the minor children.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial care and protection/adoption placement decision and the competing adoption plans of DSS and a paternal aunt. It does not address a court’s continuing jurisdiction to modify existing custody or parenting-time orders, nor does it apply a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard. The case focuses on best interests in an original disposition under G.L. c. 119 and c. 210 §3, not post-judgment modification authority, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting-time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the minor children.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30, in the context of existing joint legal and physical custody. The court discusses the “best interests of the child” standard for authorizing or denying removal, not the Probate and Family Court’s continuing jurisdiction to modify custody or parenting-time upon a material and substantial change in circumstances. While the ALI Principles excerpt mentions relocation as a substantial change, the SJC does not frame or decide the case as a modification-of-custody jurisdiction/standard question, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Upon information and belief, Father’s Partner has been the subject of at least one prior restraining order (abuse prevention order) issued under G.L. c. 209A by a court in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, arising from alleged domestic violence or abuse against a prior intimate partner.

The safety and best interests of the Chi.raw_text: The safety and best interests of the Children are the paramount concern of this Court under Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
The safety and best interests of the Chi.proposition: The safety and best interests of the Children are the paramount concern of this Court under Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The safety and best interests of the Children are the paramount concern of this Court under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal/custody matters under Massachusetts law, “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.” While the case’s focus is relocation, that statement is framed generally and reflects the governing principle in custody-related determinations, making it appropriately citable for the proposition that the children’s best interests are the court’s paramount concern.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the-interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’ Id. at 54.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The safety and best interests of the Children are the paramount concern of this Court under Massachusetts law.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the governing custody standard under Massachusetts law and reaffirms that custody must be determined according to the “best interests of the child,” citing prior Massachusetts authority that describes the children’s best interests as the paramount concern. While the case is about parental custody, not specifically a child-protection proceeding, it clearly states that in such disputes the best interests (and thus safety and welfare) of the child control the court’s decision, supporting the proposition in substance and terminology used in Massachusetts law.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (rescript)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a modification of a custody or parenting plan is warranted when a material and substantial change in circumstances makes the existing judgment inconsistent with the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for an initial custody determination on appeal, not with modification of an existing custody or parenting plan based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. It emphasizes that the welfare and best interests of the child are the governing principle for custody awards, but it does not articulate or apply the ‘material and substantial change’ standard, nor does it address modification proceedings. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about modification of custody judgments.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a modification of a custody or parenting plan is warranted when a material and substantial change in circumstances makes the existing judgment inconsistent with the best interests of the child.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: This opinion involves complaints for modification (removal and child support), but it does not articulate or apply the general Massachusetts standard that a custody/parenting plan may be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances makes the existing judgment inconsistent with the child’s best interests. The court instead focuses on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal test and on child support modification under the Guidelines. Because the decision does not state or rely on the ‘material and substantial change’ / inconsistency-with-best-interests standard for modifying custody or parenting plans, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification… For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California.… Sometime thereafter, the father filed his own complaint for modification, wherein he sought to (1) reduce his child support obligation… The cases were consolidated and tried together.… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas…”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 31, 31A.proposition: Exposure of children to violence, a history of abuse, or an environment of intimidation, yelling, or physical aggression is contrary to their best interests and weighs heavily in favor of judicial intervention and protective conditions on parenting time.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Exposure of children to violence, a history of abuse, or an environment of intimidation, yelling, or physical aggression is contrary to their best interests and weighs heavily in favor of judicial intervention and protective conditions on parenting time.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The court expressly recognizes that witnessing domestic violence or being subjected to family violence causes serious harm to children and is a critical factor in custody determinations. It faults the trial judge for not making detailed findings on the impact of such violence on the child and emphasizes that domestic violence must be explicitly considered when determining the child’s best interests, thus supporting the proposition that exposure to violence is contrary to children’s best interests and justifies judicial intervention and conditions on custody/parenting time.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm. … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Care and Protection of Rebecca, 419 Mass.raw_text: Care and Protection of Rebecca, 419 Mass. 67 (1994)
Care and Protection of Rebecca, 419 Mass.proposition: Exposure of children to violence, a history of abuse, or an environment of intimidation, yelling, or physical aggression is contrary to their best interests and weighs heavily in favor of judicial intervention and protective conditions on parenting time.
Care and Protection of Rebecca, 419 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on evidentiary and procedural issues in care and protection proceedings, particularly the admissibility and reliability of child-hearsay evidence regarding sexual abuse. It does not discuss, analyze, or establish any principle about children’s exposure to violence, intimidation, yelling, or physical aggression generally, nor does it frame such exposure as independently weighing in favor of judicial intervention or conditions on parenting time. The case is about whether evidence of alleged sexual abuse was properly admitted and sufficient to prove unfitness, not about exposure to non-sexual violence or hostile environments as a best-interests factor.

Under G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28, and G.L. c.raw_text: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 10, this Court may modify any prior judgment regarding custody or parenting time upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Under G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28, and G.L. c.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 10, this Court may modify any prior judgment regarding custody or parenting time upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20 (1981.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 10, this Court may modify any prior judgment regarding custody or parenting time upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20 (1981.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses modification of child support under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and recites that modification is conditioned on a demonstrated change in circumstances, but it does not address custody or parenting time, nor does it articulate a two-pronged test requiring both (1) material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) consistency with the child’s best interests. The case focuses on financial support modification and the effect of an increase in the payor’s income, not on custody/parenting time standards or G.L. c. 209C, § 10. Thus it only partially overlaps with the proposition and does not clearly support it as stated.
Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20 (1981.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant urges that the judgment requiring him to pay $20 more per child each week was unsupported by evidence of a material change in circumstances. In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961)… Of the several factors which the judge may consider in modifying a decree for child support, G. L. c. 208, § 28, this court has never required that they be accorded equal weight or conjunctive application.”

The \u201cbest interests of the child\u2.raw_text: The “best interests of the child” standard is the touchstone for decisions involving custody and parenting time in Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
The \u201cbest interests of the child\u2.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard is the touchstone for decisions involving custody and parenting time in Massachusetts.
The \u201cbest interests of the child\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets the governing Massachusetts removal statute, G.L. c. 208, § 30, as requiring that removal be in the best interests of the child, and then describes the custody/removal analysis as an evaluation of the child’s best interests. It further notes that the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern, confirming that this is the touchstone standard for custody/parenting‑time related decisions in this context.
The \u201cbest interests of the child\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

The Court is specifically required to co.raw_text: The Court is specifically required to consider evidence of abuse, patterns of domestic violence, and the safety of the child when making or modifying custody and parenting arrangements. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209A; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Care and Protection of Rebecca, 419 Mass. 67 (1994).
The Court is specifically required to co.proposition: The Court is specifically required to consider evidence of abuse, patterns of domestic violence, and the safety of the child when making or modifying custody and parenting arrangements.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The Court is specifically required to consider evidence of abuse, patterns of domestic violence, and the safety of the child when making or modifying custody and parenting arrangements.

Massachusetts courts have recognized tha.raw_text: Massachusetts courts have recognized that changes in the home environment, including the presence of new adult household members and exposure to conflict or violence, can constitute a material change warranting modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time judgment. See Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
Massachusetts courts have recognized tha.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that changes in the home environment, including the presence of new adult household members and exposure to conflict or violence, can constitute a material change warranting modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time judgment.
Massachusetts courts have recognized tha.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a removal request and a child support modification, not a modification of custody or parenting time based on changes in the home environment. The “change in circumstances” discussed is the mother’s remarriage and desire to relocate, not the introduction of new adult household members in a way that alters the children’s home environment, nor exposure to conflict or violence. The court does not analyze whether such environmental changes constitute a material change warranting modification of custody or parenting time, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Massachusetts courts have recognized tha.relevant_excerpt: “On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification alleging, as a change in circumstances, that she was to be married on August 3, 2012, to a resident of Danville, California. For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California. … The cases were consolidated and tried together.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that changes in the home environment, including the presence of new adult household members and exposure to conflict or violence, can constitute a material change warranting modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time judgment.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of child support in light of Social Security disability dependency benefits, an attachment to secure support and college expenses, and the standard for modifying legal custody. It does not discuss changes in the home environment, new adult household members, or exposure to conflict or violence as grounds for modifying custody or parenting time. The only custody-related discussion is about the parents’ inability to communicate and the need for findings on best interests, not environmental changes in the custodial home.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’”

The Court has broad equitable power to c.raw_text: The Court has broad equitable power to craft appropriate conditions on visitation and parenting time, including restrictions on contact with particular third parties and requirements for supervised parenting time, to safeguard the child’s welfare. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Vinson v. Vinson, 364 Mass. 491 (1974); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
The Court has broad equitable power to c.proposition: The Court has broad equitable power to craft appropriate conditions on visitation and parenting time, including restrictions on contact with particular third parties and requirements for supervised parenting time, to safeguard the child’s welfare.

Vinson v. Vinson, 364 Mass. 491 (1974).proposition: The Court has broad equitable power to craft appropriate conditions on visitation and parenting time, including restrictions on contact with particular third parties and requirements for supervised parenting time, to safeguard the child’s welfare.
Vinson v. Vinson, 364 Mass. 491 (1974).support_reasoning: This is a Massachusetts eminent domain valuation case involving expert testimony about reproduction cost and depreciation for a taken church property. It does not involve family law, visitation, parenting time, or judicial authority to impose conditions on parent–child contact. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition about equitable power to regulate visitation or require supervision or restrictions on third-party contact.
Vinson v. Vinson, 364 Mass. 491 (1974).relevant_excerpt: We believe the Commonwealth’s sole exception is limited to the narrow issue of whether Keefe was qualified to testify as an expert on the basis of the reproduction cost method. … The petitioner’s witness employed the restoration cost analysis as his method for determining depreciation. We hold that in the light of his experience and training it was proper to admit his testimony on the basis of the method he selected.
